text:
Been using Julia for < 1 day, so pardon any dumb questions...
I installed the Plots package (`using Pkg; pkg.Add("Plots")`).
(1) Then the first time I did `using Plots`, I saw "`[ Info: Precompiling Plots [91a5bcdd-55d7-5caf-9e0b-520d859cae80]``" for about 15-20 seconds.
(2) Further, when I used `plot(x, y)` for the first time, it took about 4 seconds to plot and faster thereafter.

Q1: Is (2) just an effect of JIT? Also is ~4 seconds really the time it'll take the first time or have I installed something incorrectly?
Q2: What's the reason for (2) and is the time it took normal?
(I use Ubuntu 16.04 w/ 16GB Intel Core™ i7-6700 CPU @ 3.40GHz × 8

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/54736| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
That is normal. Its something that every julia update tries to reduce but it is a result of JIT

text: From what I've seen you have installed everything correctly and the time is normal. The specifics about why exactly plots is slow to compile I don't know

text: This is the well known "time to first plot" issue. If you search the julia discourse for that, you'll find a lot of discussion about what causes it and how to reduce the impact (both from a workflow and package development level).

elements.text: This is the well known "time to first plot" issue. If you search the julia discourse for that, you'll find a lot of discussion about what causes it and how to reduce the impact (both from a workflow and package development level).

text: Yes. Some pats of the Plots package are precompiled the first time you `using Plots`. That is what takes the time then. This does not process everything in Plots, although it does a good deal of the work.  The first time (in a session) that you actually plot something, Julia compiles the remaining functions it encounters while computing and constructing the plot. After that first plot, the work does not need to be repeated so subsequent plots come up quickly.

After that first plot, the work does not need to be repeated so subsequent plots come up quickly.
